attributes.comment:
As an employee of an Immigration attorney, I see the clients? needs. I know the
people who are most desperate to keep their families intact, as well as where they
stand financially. I also see the intense pressure and stress that Immigration
regulations and waiting times can put upon people's lives.
Is it too much to ask that a person be allowed to attend to their dying parents in
their home country? As the home of the free, we are supposed to be humane.
Does the phrase "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses, yearning
to breath free" have no meaning in the current climate of terrorism and fear?
The people that this agency was created to serve have come here for two basic
reasons: to make a better life for themselves and their families or because their
families (spouse, children, parents) have already made a better life and the family
wants to be reunited.
The proposed fees place an enormous burden upon the US Citizen petitioners that
are trying to unite their family. Already, waiting times cause families to miss
spectacular and life altering events because they can not go home, or their child
can not come to the US, because that child is waiting on a visa.
A 20% reduction in processing times does NOT justify a 60% increase in fees.
Under the rules of VAWA, a spouse of a US Citizen, who has been abused by
said US Citizen must wait over 9 months (at the current processing times) for their
initial visa application to be approved before they can even apply for permanent
residence. Then there must be an additional wait of 7 months for their Permanent
Residency application to be approved. This the best case scenario assuming that
there is no additional evidence requested (many times incorrectly or
unnecessarily). This abused spouse, often without any family or support in
America, must often wait 16 months before they can have peace of mind that their
abusive spouse can no longer hurt them and they can stay and work in America.
This VAWA applicant is most likely not in a position to make any money or
receive any employment until after their application is on file. These applicants
struggle to pay the current filing fees, and yet they are expected to pay the new
fees that have increased 60% for a decrease of about three months in processing
time.
Unacceptable.
On the USCIS.gov home page a statement is made. "Securing America's
Promise." What is this promise? That they will be financially skewered for a very
small perceivable gain?
I understand that technology is expensive, but USCIS has made great gains in the
last year with a decrease in processing times. Although still unacceptable,
progress HAS been made WITHOUT increasing fees by 60%.
Do not allow this increase to occur. Thank you for your concern in this matter.
From:
A native-born 4th Generation American
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Anita W. Faulkner
